posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The first posts here are moved by Moderator Mick Dagger from the thread Gloom Razor of the Hin.


I'm coming back to this thread after a long hiatus, due to new changes on the PW where I play (World of Greyhawk).

Gloomrazer, as originally created by GDL, is no longer anywhere near as effective as it used to be due to activation of specific parts of Tony K's AI that makes breaking LoS (aggro) and Stealthing a problem (meaning it does not work!!!).  As this new behavior did not exist before on WoG, it was not a problem.

But now it is, and it is a painful one.

The solution, is HiPS.

So, I am going with the Rogue/CoT/SD build, to see how it performs.  I am selecting the Halfling build - Halfling (Rogue 25/FTR 14/SD 1) by Mithdradates, located here - http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 17502.html

My question here is, should I continue with a report on how this build does in this thread (knowing full well that it is NOT a Gloomrazer)?  Or should I put it somewhere else?

posts.author: Sandii
posts.content:
Hello everyone,

I think it would fit well here. I came across this build through various links and it is recommended as an entry-level build for Wog. I tested it into the late 30s and wasn't happy with the performance. As a comparison, I tested gloomstalker (link), which are similar in terms of talent adjustment (except for SC and better saves) and felt significantly better with hips.

Gloomrazer, as originally created by GDL, is no longer anywhere near as effective as it used to be due to activation of specific parts of Tony K's AI that makes breaking LoS (aggro) and Stealthing a problem (meaning it does not work!!!).  As this new behavior did not exist before on WoG, it was not a problem.

But now it is, and it is a painful one.

The solution, is HiPS.

So, I am going with the Rogue/CoT/SD build, to see how it performs.  I am selecting the Halfling build - Halfling (Rogue 25/FTR 14/SD 1) by Mithdradates, located here - http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/buil ... 17502.html

My question here is, should I continue with a report on how this build does in this thread (knowing full well that it is NOT a Gloomrazer)?  Or should I put it somewhere else?
I will suggest that you make a new topic eg. in the general discussion forum where you describe the changes to the AI and how it affects stealth play. Then you can share your experiences with a HIPS build compared with a non-HIPS rogue build

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: What changes to the AI? I haven't detected any. I haven't seen any changes posted either. And I just played this not long ago and had zero issues....

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
grizzled_dwarflord wrote: ↑
Oct 24, 2023
What changes to the AI? I haven't detected any. I haven't seen any changes posted either. And I just played this not long ago and had zero issues....
Here's the link to Web's recent thread over on the WoG site, where this gets an airing: Sneak Wonkiness

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
grizzled_dwarflord wrote: ↑
Oct 24, 2023
What changes to the AI? I haven't detected any. I haven't seen any changes posted either. And I just played this not long ago and had zero issues....
I will name a specific area for you to test - Stone Giants.  I suspect (it is my experiences and findings) that the activation of Tony K's "Swarm" AI feature (where nearby faction members can silently "call" for help, Rez fallen comrades, etc) is the main culprit here (and as it is active with Stone Giants, one gets a first hand experience with it).

Where my Gloomrazer (the one that I played to level 40 in this thread) was able to easily tronce the place, it now gets wrecked.  Granted, I was not using Epic Traps, as I did not expect to have to.

The main problem being, first of all, that the Giants swarm you now, they cannot be "plinked" and then disposed of individually.  That, in and of itself, would not be a serious problem, if not for the fact that ducking around a corner and hiding (activating sneak) DOES NOT WORK!!!!  The aggroed opponents will continue right at you, regardless (and they even went through a field of Darkness as if it was not there! And no, they do not have Ultravision, vanilla TS, etc).  The inclusion now of mighty (and many) spellcasters complicates the matter, due to the Eldar Riftlords bombing you with dispels, extremely high level Fingers of Death, Ice Storms, and total ignorance of stealth and any attempt to delay them.  The Cyclops Warpriests are nasty, and rez constantly from the security of GS (that works, for them, but not for us Players).

As such, it is basically almost suicide for Gloomrazer to poke it's nose in there - not up to and including the Gates, but beyond that (where one runs into a literal HORDE of nasty opponents, just slavering to mash you into a pulp).

HiPS, on the other hand, does not suffer from this, it shuts aggro down, IMMEDIATELY!  That makes it possible to use the main weapons of the Gloomer - Crippling Strike, to reduce Str (and therefore combat effectiveness) AND gets the swarm to stop attacking all at once (not to mention breaking the spell targeting of spellcasters). It is this factor (and this alone) that has convinced me to go with a HiPS based Gloomy.

Now, I am sure that oodles of Epic Trap fields would win the day - but that is not really a Gloomrazer highpoint (it is more a point of any build that can lay down such traps).

Note that without the valuable feedback from sandii, I would have never experienced this, because I have already levelled Gloomrazer to 40 and saw no need to muck around in old stomping grounds.  So a big thank you to sandii, for giving me this feedback, so that I could go there, test, and get totally wrecked...hehe.

And by that, I mean like 10 times in a row (4 to Finger of Death, I know, I know, I roll 1s all the time, but still...meh) and the other 6 times just squashed like a bug.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Well, this new build (it's actually old) - Halfling (Rogue 25/FTR 14/SD 1) by Mithdradates, is performing way better than I expected (considering the beginning difficulties I had with Gloomrazer, this build just breezes through stuff).

Now at level 20 (epic) where the fun starts...not meaning it was not fun to get here (because it was!).

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content: Up to 23 now.  Would be higher, but the PW crashed!

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: Well, HiPS makes everything better. That’s a no-brainer. We’ve already built oodles of those things.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
webshaman1 wrote: ↑
Oct 24, 2023
 Gloomrazer, as originally created by GDL, is no longer anywhere near as effective as it used to be due to activation of specific parts of Tony K's AI that makes breaking LoS (aggro) and Stealthing a problem (meaning it does not work!!!).  As this new behavior did not exist before on WoG, it was not a problem.

But now it is, and it is a painful one.

The solution, is HiPS.
The essential issue - for WoG at least - still remains, however. It surely can't be right that HiPS is now the only way to stealth successfully (and apparently GS doesn't work either)? How many builds does that trash? Certainly an awful lot of Dexers who have stealth but no Epic Dodge to assist them - and that comes at L27 at the earliest.

Do we know if Improved Invisibility is still okay? Or - as another mitigator - Empty Body?

Is anyone planning on fixing it, because I don't think this effect is what was desired?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Improved Invis works as designed (as does Empty Body) - as long as the opponents do not have access to either See Invisibility (or an ability that is similar, like Creature Feats), or Invisibility Purge.

And the negation of normal Stealth is only where the Swarm AI is active - I have tested this, and in areas of WoG where the Swarm AI part of Tony K's AI is not active, breaking LoS and Stealthing works normally.

Fazit: Avoid using Stealthing tactics where the Swarm AI is active - switch to a different one.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content: My Gloomy Hazer is now level 29, has Crippling Strike, Epic Dodge, and HiPS...let the pain begin!  Woooohooooo!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: So, can't someone just turn off Swarm AI? I suppose I'm being too simplistic, and it would have other effects - the old "butterfly flutters its wings in Japan, tsunami in Switzerland" scenario.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If this is a WoG problem, then it should definitely be addressed there. And I have noticed that there is a thread about it already in the WoG forum.

I would guess that this issue may appear elsewhere too, where Tony's AI is involved. After all it has widespread use. So I welcome that we shed light on the issue here as well.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
DM Wise has turned on Swarm AI in specific areas to heighten the difficulty level.

That, by itself, is working as designed.

It just means that some tactics that before were working, don't anymore.  Adjust, adapt, conquer.

So, my Gloomy Hazer is performing perfectly, slaughtering those Stonies (and Eldar Riftlords, Cloppy Warpriests, etc) with impunity!  Where Gloomrazer got trounced, Gloomy Hazer excells.  Hurrah!  Level 31 now.  Just adding to AB and AC now (and getting skill areas up).

Fazit : HiPS combined with Crippling Strike and Epic Dodge is a game winner!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: ↑
Oct 26, 2023
So, can't someone just turn off Swarm AI? I suppose I'm being too simplistic, and it would have other effects - the old "butterfly flutters its wings in Japan, tsunami in Switzerland" scenario.
Now, yes, if the Swarm AI feature is turned back off (it is blocked out by default iirc) then normal stealthing works as designed and the tactic of breaking LoS and then stealthing is back.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I'm updating this with new information:

DM Wise has done some testing on this, with the exact same creatures and place as I.

It was brought to my attention that a particular opponent (Eldar Riftlords, one can consider them Stone Giant Archdruids) may have a high enough Spot to detect Gloomrazer normal Stealth.  Due to the AI changes for that area, i.e. Swarm AI, that creature can then "impart" this information to others of the same faction - sort of like it is directing the others to the place where they can see Gloomrazer as being.

This actually makes sense (to me) and I would not consider this to be a bug, if that is indeed what is happening.

What it doesn't explain, however, is why my Gloomy Hazer (who uses HiPS in place of normal Stealth), who has far lower Stealth values (because it is "only" level 30), is not detected by these Eldar Riftlords, or, perhaps it is, and the function of HiPS is causing the AI to "short circuit" out of Spot.  I know that the activation of HiPS immediately stops aggro.  Does it also halt Spot checks as well?

So my question is, is there a Passive and an Active part of Stealth checking?  And if there is, is the Passive checks then so much lower than the Active ones?

I will be checking on the normal Stealth, boosting the 60s up to 100+, to see if this makes a difference (it should be impossible for anything to detect Stealth values over 100 without some sort of vanilla TS).

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
New updates:

GDLs Gloomrazer will work in 99.99% of the areas of WoG as it is in his build.  Only the Stone Giant Lair changes things, due to the whopping ability to spot those hiding.

At least, this is the direct feedback from DM Wise on that particular area and what is most likely happening.  So Gloomrazer is probably going to need some major additions to the stealth area.  One thing that will help is a Wand of Mass Camoflage (+10).  My Gloomrazer has 60s in Stealth, so that would bump it up to 70s.  Still not enough, apparently.  So, any ideas other than using Stealth boosting items?  I suspect having Stealth in the 100s should do the trick (though it might not, depending on how much Spot those Eldar Riftlords have).

Since apparently HiPS shuts down the "detection loop", it basically cuts right through this type of Stealth detection, meaning there is no need for the above concerns (especially since it can be reactivated, even if it is on a timer on WoG).

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Without seeing the actual AI scripts I can't say for sure, but it's possible that this issue is due to NPCs not percieving that they can't percieve you.

All creatures in NWN have a perception list of creatures that they can see / hear.
Generally speaking, those perception lists are updated every 0.2 secs for PCs and every 4 secs for NPCs.
HiPS will attempt to remove the sneaker from perception lists immediately when entering stealth mode, skipping the usual update delays.

If you're visible to an NPC and run around a wall then it can take up to 4 secs before the NPC realises that it can't actually see you since you're out of their line of sight.
However if you have HiPS, run around a wall, and enter stealth mode then the NPC will immediately un-see you since you're out of their line of sight.

Vanilla AI (and possibly Tony K AI) only reacts to enemies that can be seen, it ignores enemies that are heard but aren't seen.
So once you HiPS after breaking LoS the NPCs can no longer see you and therefore stop attempting to attack you.
However, when corner-sneaking NPCs will still try to attack you for up to 4 secs before realising they can't see you, possibly giving them time to get LoS on your character and actually see you.
If Tony K AI does react to heard enemies then anything within a roughly 20m radius (easily changed via 2da) can potentially be heard, even through walls.
So you would need to break LoS and be more than 20m away from any NPCs to be sure that you aren't detected.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Understanding the detection mechanism that Yunim explains is indeed important here.
The great thing with HIPS is that it even works "in plain sight".
The 4 second delay for NPCs can be exploited by "spamming" HIPS, even with a character build with relatively low stealth skills.
Many PWs have a cool down time on HIPS limiting it to eg. once per round.

posts.author: Relka
posts.content:
What interesting insight into the game mechanics. If I understand correctly, the removal from the perception list will also empty the action queue of affected opponents ?
Thus wasting their current round of actions/attacks ?

Does the Spot check happen before that forced removal ? Meaning that with high enough skill, you could avoid that purging of the action queue and waste of attack rounds ?
From my experience, it always seemed when faced with HiPS it was really hard to get my character to do anything, but maybe it was because of not high enough skills.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Yes, without a cool-down (timer) on HiPS, an exceptionally good Player (or the AI) can HiPS the Action Queue to death.

Basically, immune to anything.

It works like this for a Player - Quickslot  Attack and HiPS on the Quickbar by each other.  I normally use slots 1 and 2.  Then, I normally just put my left hand over the F1-F2 Keys, and toggle them like 1,2,1 - which will drop you out of Attack (because Attack used while Attacking de-selects it), and immediately enter you into HiPS then (because you cannot HiPS directly when attacking).  The Attack then allows one to contine attacking from HiPS after emptying the enemy Action Queue.

This will even sort of work despite having a Timer, or Cooldown.  One will not actually enter HiPS, but it will work to drop the Action Queue, forcing the opponent to "fill it up" again.
